w:r.w:t: Section 1. The Incarnation and Sufferings of the Son of God
be the Wisdom and the Power,
That joined in council to restore
And we his children thus were brought
To death and near to hell.
Blest be the Lord who sent His Son,
To take our flesh and blood.
To bring us life He gave His own,
And made our peace with God.
He honoured all His Father's laws
Ile bore our sins upon the cross,
Behold Him rising from the grave,
He pleads His merit there to save
There on a glorious throne He reigns,
Redeems us from the slavish chains
Thence soon the Son of God shall come,
Shall call His saints forth from the tomb
Yet by faith we read the words—
King of kings and Lord of lords.
See! He stands at Pilate's bar,
Most despised of all by far;
Still to Him belong the words—
King of kings and Lord of lords.
He who wears the crown of thorns,
He whom man reviles and scorns, Yet demands as His the words—King of kings and Lord of lords.
On the cross 'tis still the same,
Never can He yield His claim
King of kings and Lord of lords.
Past the conflict of His love,
See He takes His place above;
On His vesture shine the words—
King of kings and Lord of lords.
Gathered by the call of God,
We rejoice, though once we trembled,
Let us trace the path He trod:
In the Babe in David's city,
Him by whom the world was made.
Faithful to His task and true,
That His kingly hands would do.
View the Man of Sorrows, treading
Earth's dark vale of sin and woe,
Slain by men His love befriended,
'Neath the wrath of God He died.
Now He lives no more to die.
On the Father's throne He's seated,
'Tis by Him we now draw nigh.
For His birth and life obedient
For His death, no mere expedient,
Blessed God, would praise Thee still.
Praise the Father, for He gave us
Gift most precious in His Son.
Praise the Son, for He to save us
Such a mighty work has done.
FROM the realm of light and glory
Came the Son of God as Man, To unfold the wondrous story
Stepping down to earth's dark night—
Shepherds find Him in a manger,
Gaze in wonder at the sight!
All His steps we love to trace.
On the cross, His will unshaken,
To the Father's side He rises,
There to take the highest seat!
Tribute bring we to the Father
For the Son, His gift of love;
Bowing low, our praise we offer
bless and praise Thee, gracious God,
Who did partake of flesh and blood,
Well may we wonder at the thought
That Christ came down so low,
That He so near to us was brought To understand our woe.
He, mingling with the human race,
Saw sin, death, Satan's power; Before His holy piercing gaze
But not alone in living strife
Upon the cross He gave His life;
For us He died upon the tree,
For us was shed His blood,
But more than that since unto Thee
Its fragrant worth no tongue can tell,
And in the Holy Spirit we
He lives no more to die;
Before Thy face we own His grace, He once for us was poor.
We bless His name, we sing His fame, He liveth evermore.
Our hymn of praise with joy we raise,
His worth no tongue can tell.
So great His love all praise above,
He hath done all things well.
Came forth the Son most holy To manifest His love.
The Lord of life and glory;
He lived a life most holy
Through this dark vale of sorrow
In Him each sick and sad one
Oh, well may we adore Him,
For us His Son He gave;
He died our souls to save;
The star is dimmed that lately shone;
E'en that disciple whom He loved
Heeds not his Master's grief and tears.
The sweat falls down like drops of blood;
Yet He who such deep anguish feels
Is not forsaken by His God.
Yet darker hours of deeper woe;
The patient Saviour needs must know.
0 God, those midnight scenes of woe
We bless the One who loved us so,
And fully own that Christ is all.
Son of God, the Prince of life,
The sword was drawn to pierce the One
On whom our sins were laid.
He asked, if it were possible,
Made flesh for us, the Son of God
Strong crying, tears and sweat like blood
Yet must He sink in deeper grief
Till God has slain His Son;
The Christ must die on Golgotha
Ponder His pretaste of the cup,
The Lamb of God the sacrifice,
Whatever curse was ours He bore,
There in that lone mysterious hour
Our cup He drained it all.
The Lord Himself and none beside
Nor other tell the joy's full tide That from that cup shall flow.
The joy is His, yet wondrous grace,
That joy to us is given;
Our joy to His sorerief we trace,
His death brings life and heaven.
And, while the ages roll along,
And this the new and endless song—
His love to us, to me.
Lamb of God to slaughter led,
A crown of thorns upon His head;
They nail Him to the tree.
The Father gives His only Son,
For us the guilty and undone,
Thy name is holy, 0 our God,
The holy place is our abode,
Enthroned with Thee now sits the Lord,
Justice that smote Him with the sword
Eternal death was once our doom,
Now death has lost its sting; Triumphant through His empty tomb,
Thy power and love we sing.
While our hearts in worship bow,
There we read the wondrous story
Of the cross, its shame and woe.
All the depths of His heart's sorrow
Where no pitying eye was found;
Now to God's right hand exalted—
With His praise the heavens resound.
Did His God e'en then forsake Him,
Hide Himself from His deep need?
In that face, once marred and smitten,
All His glory now we read.
Rise, our hearts, and bless the Father;
To the Father and the Son.
How deep and grievous was the woe
It laid the mighty Saviour low
To bring us gain He bare the pain,
The wage of sin was in our cup,
Wrath filled it to the brim;
That cup was drunk by Him.
'Twas all for us He suffered thus,
That we might live through Him.
There rose a keen relentless storm,
marred His visage and His form,
But thus He saved His own.
He bore the grief for our relief,
He bare the brunt of all God's ire,
And thus our peace was won.
The stripes were sore the Saviour bore;
His wrathful sword was raised to smite
The One who pleased Him well;
On Him in whom He had delight
Our peace He made, the price He paid;
His love no tongue can tell.
It was for us Christ Jesus died,
Of love He has to us.
He is our Lord alone adored
The One who suffered grief and shame Is raised and glorified.
We sing the triumph of His name
Who groaned and bled and died. We celebrate His triumph great;
As we survey the wondrous cross
On which the Lord of glory died,
Our richest gains we count but loss, And pour contempt on all our pride.
Forbid that we should ever boast
Save in the cross of Christ, 0 God;
All the vain things that charmed us most,
We sacrifice them to His blood.
See from His head, His hands, His feet,
Sorrow and love flow mingled down;
Did e'er such love and sorrow meet,
Or thorns compose so rich a crown?
Were the whole realm of nature ours,
That were an offering far too small;
Love that transcends our highest powers
Demands our heart, our life, our all.
Lo. He dies upon the tree;
And declare the love of God.
See who hears the awful load;
Son of Man and Son of God!
Lamb of God, for sinners wounded,
Who on Him their hopes have built.
Faint and bleeding, who is He?
Hands and feet so rudely torn,
Wreathed with crown of twisted thorn.
Once He lived in heaven above,
Mocked and taunted, who is He? Scorners tell Him to come down,
Claim His kingdom and His crown.
He it was who came to bless,
Son of Man, 'Os He, 'tis He, Nailed upon Golgotha's tree.
As a Victim, who is He?
Bearing sin, but not His own,
For the sinner bleeds and dies;
Lamb of God, 'tis He, 'tis He, Nailed upon Golgotha's tree.
0 LovE divine, what hast thou done!
The Christ of God for us hath bled;
Had all our sins upon Him laid.
The Son of God for us hath died,
Our Lord, our Life was crucified.
Was crucified for us in shame
To bring us rebels back to God.
So may we glory in His name,
As those redeemed by precious blood. Pardon and fife flowed from His side,
When He our Lord was crucified.
Then let us glory in the
Make Christ our boast, our constant All things for Him account but loss,
And now for Him despise the shame.
Let nought with Him our hearts divide
Since He for us was crucified.
He could not save, He on the cross must die,
Yes, Christ the Son of God must bleed,
That sinners might from sin be freed.
Our sins' full weight must fall
For nothing less could God accept
In payment of that fearful debt.
To pay the debt we owed. Obedience to the Father's will
And love to Him did all fulfil.
Has saved and brought us nigh.
We live in Him who lives above,
And sing with joy His deathless love.
The sword of God was bidden
His Son who pleased Him well;
He pierced His soul, nor spared Him
When bruised by earth and hell.
He said, " I am a worm.
The sinner's place was taken By Him our glorious Lord.
His God who duly prized Him,
In floods of death baptized Him,
He was the Father's treasure, The Christ whom He had sent;
On Him for us was spent.
But dead with Him and buried,
And raised to share His bliss,
So full of pain and scorn,
Mocked with a crown of thorn,
In death once bowed and wounded,
No bone of Him was broken—
Of life and peace a token
To us who know His name. The Head for all the members
Was our sins' heavy load, We had the debt augmented
Which He then paid in blood.
Doth in our hearts take place,
When we His toil and passion
Ah! should we while thus musing
Great gain would be that loss.
For Him the Friend in need, For what His soul sustained
When He for us did bleed.
To see Him face to face.
What Christ did sow in tears,
The feast which we are keeping
From Him the face of God,
His death of shame and sorrow
To our eternal home, Its joy already tasting
We watch the dawn of day.
Of the wrath and curse of God.
On His pale and suffering brow,
On His grief and sore amaze
We would fix our earnest gaze.
Oh how precious in our eyes!
He alone our rest shall be,
is the savour of His name
Who suffered in His people's stead;
His portion here reproach and shame, He liveth now, He once was dead.
He once was dead, the very same
Who sits on yonder throne above,
Who bears in heaven the greatest name,
Whom angels serve, whom angels love.
He once was dead, the very same
Who made the worlds, a work of power,
Who now upholds the mighty frame,
And keeps it till the final hour.
He once was dead; but now He lives,
His glory fills all heaven above;
Its blessedness to heaven He gives,
The fountain He of joy and love.
His people shall His triumph share,
With Him shall live and with Him reign,
In heaven their joy is full, for there
They see Him who for them was slain.
us join our God to bless
Him who bowed His head so low
His the curse, the wounds, the gall,
His the stripes, He bore them all;
His the dying cry of pain
When our sins He did sustain.
From the vanquished grave did rise.
Free Himself, He set us free
Praise our God who willed it thus,
Praise His Son who died for us,
Praise the Father for the Son
Who so vast a work hath done.
Who would hush the heaven-sent story
Of the One who came to die?
Down to Calvary's depth of woe;
Now on high, we bow before Him,
He is on the Father's throne;
Sing till heaven and earth surprising
He shall reign and He alone.
Where the Father's love and glory
Shine in all their brightest rays.
Heaven and earth alike confess Him
As the ever great I AM.
Lamb of God, His Father's bosom
One with Him in power and grace. Oh, what wondrous love and mercy
Thus to lay His glory by,
As the Lamb of God to die!
Lamb of God, when we behold Him
In the world His hands had made,
When we see Him in the garden. Anguish forcing drops like blood, At His grace we are confounded,
When we see Him as the Victim
Bound upon Golgotha's cross, For our guilt and folly stricken,
Lord, we own, with hearts adoring,
He has loved us unto blood;
Be unto the Lamb of God!
MAN of Sorrows! what a name
For the Son of God, who came
In my place condemned He stood,
Sealed my pardon with His blood.
Spotless Lamb of God was He;
Lifted up was He to die,
When He comes, the glorious King,
All His ransomed home to bring,
Then anew this song we'll sing,
love of God, it melts our hearts,
And fills our eyes with grateful tears,
When Justice stern in wrath arose
With sword uplift and keen, Poor helpless sinners to dispatch,
Between that mighty sword and us
That fearful stroke, it fell on Him,
And life for us was won.
God's love to us will never cease,
Then unto God be glory given,
And let us praise Him now
While at His throne we bow.
Goo is love, His word has said it,
This is news of heavenly birth;
In our hearts His Spirit shed it,
Made us know it here on earth,
Where the Lord, in glory crowned,
Will the brightest proof be found
All His love how vast it is;
Earth's the favoured spot He chooses
To display the truth of this—
But in heaven of highest wonder,
His a throne, the throne of heaven,
Yet He comes to earth to bleed,
And for man His life is given.
Not for those who ever loved Him
Did the Lord of glory die;
Pity to the wretched moved Him,
Who that hears it will deny
Let us lowly now adore Him,
Triune God of love and grace;
Joyful bow the knee before Him,
Laud His goodness, sound His praise,
To speak Thy worth and sing Thy praise,
For love that made Thee give Thy Son
On Him by Thee our sins were laid,
When He for sin atonement made;
Our every sin was known to Thee,
He bore them that we might be free.
That Thou for us Thy Son shouldst send
To bear such heavy load of woe,
To pay the debt that we did owe.
But this we know, Thy Son did die
To bring us guilty sinners nigh.
Now all the work is fully done,
We stand accepted in Thy Son.
And now we wait the happy day
When He will take His own away,
Far from this scene of care and strife,
To dwell with Him in endless life.
Till then, 0 God, be this our aim,
To praise the love that made Thee give
Thy Son to die that we might live.
to Thee our voice we lift
In praise for every perfect gift
In daily boons bestowed by Thee
Thou hast declared Thyself to be
A God of grace and love.
But oh, Thy Son, from heaven sent,
For Him, our songs to Thee we raise In thankful gratitude and praise,
The gift that makes Thee known.
What love it was, that Thou shouldst give
Thy Son to death that we might live, Who bore no love to Thee!
No thanks we gave for aught bestowed,
But by our every action showed
But now we love, for love expressed
In giving us Thy very best—
We praise Thee, worship and adore,
Who opened thus love's boundless store
Oh, wondrous gift, in whom we find
Our life, our peace, our righteousness;
All that we have and shall possess,
We have in Him, from Thee.
To Thee is highest glory due,
And ages shall its weight accrue,
For this that Thou hast done.
So now we'd join that mighty song
That age on age shall echo on,
Who gave for us His well-beloved Son,
The gift of gifts, all other gifts in one;
Who gave for us this mighty gift unbought,
'Tis this that silences each rising fear,
'Tis this that bids the hard thought disappear;
Since Christ has died and risen and gone above,
For us to plead at the right hand of Love?
Who shall recall His pardon or His grace?
Or who the broken chain of guilt replace?
For us in might came forth the Mighty One;
For us He fought the fight, the triumph won;
Love that no tongue can teach,
Love that no thought can reach,
Death ne'er can stop its course,
Blest in this love we sing,
His love and grace adore, Who all our sorrows bore;
Tell what His arm hath done,
Sing, we who know His blood Hath brought us nigh to God,
And crowned us with all good,
Join in one song of love,
Praise to His name. To Him ascribed be
Oh, what a gift Thy Son!
He all Thy will has done,
We sing Thy power and love,
Him who gave, and Him who died,
Him who with us doth abide.
Glory be to Him who gave
His own Son our souls to save,
Sent Him down from heaven above
Lord of earth and Lord of heaven, Who for us His life hath given.
He doth to our hearts make sure
All the goodness of our God,
All the worth of Jesus' blood.
Love of Father, love of Son,
Led Thee to give Thy Son, To yield Thy Well-beloved
To give Thy Well-beloved for us.
What led the Son of God
To leave His throne on high,
Led Him to die and suffer thus.
Moved Thee to give Thy Spirit thus.
To teach us all Thy love,
And tell of Him who died?
To condescend to dwell with us.
What love to Thee we owe,
Help us, 0 God, to praise Thee thus For all Thy boundless love to us.
To God the Father's love, For all our comforts here
He sent His own eternal Son
To die for sins that we had done.
Who bought us with His blood
And now He lives and soon will reign
To see the fruit of all His pain.
His work completes the great design
And fills the soul with joy divine.
Where reason fails with all her powers,
There faith prevails and love adores.
Section 2. The Lord's Resurrection and Triumph
Low in the grave He lay,
Up from the grave He arose
With a mighty triumph o'er His foes;
He arose a Victor from the dark domain,
And He lives for ever with His saints to reign;
the Lord is risen to-day, Hallelujah!
Sons of men and angels say, Hallelujah!
Raise your joys and triumphs high, Hallelujah!
Sing, ye heavens, and earth reply, Hallelujah!
Love's redeeming work is done, Hallelujah!
Fought the fight, the battle won, Hallelujah! Lo, our Sun's eclipse is o'er, Hallelujah!
Lo, He sets in death no more, Hallelujah!
Vain the stone, the watch, the seal, Hallelujah!
Christ hath burst the gates of Sheol, Hallelujah!
Death in vain forbids Him rise, Hallelujah!
Lives again the glorious King, Hallelujah!
Where, 0 Death, is now thy sting? Hallelujah!
Once He died our souls to save, Hallelujah! Where's thy victory, 0 Grave? Hallelujah!
Lord of earth and heaven He is, Hallelujah!
Him to know, His power to prove, Hallelujah!
Him to laud, and Him to love, Hallelujah! Amen.
the day that sees Him rise, Hallelujah!
To the throne above the skies, Hallelujah!
Christ, whose life for us was given, Hallelujah!
Enters now the highest heaven, Hallelujah!
There for Him high triumph waits, Hallelujah!
Lift your heads, eternal gates, Hallelujah!
He has conquered death and sin, Hallelujah! Let the King of glory in, Hallelujah!
See, He lifts His hands above, Hallelujah!
See, He shows the prints of love, Hallelujah!
Hark, His gracious lips bestow, Hallelujah!
Blessings on His saints below, Hallelujah!
There for us He intercedes, Hallelujah!
His atoning death He pleads, Hallelujah!
Near Himself prepares our place, Hallelujah! In the riches of His grace, Hallelujah!
Now He's parted from our sight, Hallelujah!
Far above the starry height, Hallelujah!
Soon for us He'll come again, Hallelujah!
Christ, who for our sins was slain, Hallelujah!
He shall come and take us home, Hallelujah!
From Him we no more shall roam, Hallelujah! Sing His glory, hymn His praise, Hallelujah!
gates, lift up your heads on high;
Ye doors that last for aye,
Be lifted up, that so the King
But who of glory is the King?
E'en that same Lord that great in might
Ye gates, lift up your heads; ye doors,
Doors that do last for aye,
Be lifted up, that so the King
But who is He that is the King
The Lord of hosts, and none but He,
Praise Jehovah! Bless Jehovah! Hallelujah! Amen, amen, amen.
Since Jesus liveth, who was dead.
Since Jesus liveth, who was dead.
On Him our help was laid,
Since Jesus liveth, who was dead.
Since Jesus liveth, who was dead.
In all His works behold Him great, Before, almighty to create,
He's risen now, His people's Head,
And if like Him they yield their breath,
Like Him they'll burst the bonds of
Why should His people then be sad?
None have such reason to be glad
As those redeemed to God. Jesus the mighty Saviour lives, To them eternal life He gives,
Then let our gladsome praise resound,
And let us in His work abound,
We're sure our labour's not in vain,
For we with Him ere long shall reign,
Mercy and Truth are now agreed,
The captive Surety now is freed,
He lives to die no more,
He lives His people's cause to plead,
Whose curse and shame He bore.
And with Him all the ransomed seed
He won the meed and crown;
Trod all our foes beneath His feet
He hell in hell laid low,
Bowed to the grave, destroyed it so,
Bless, bless the Conqueror slain, Slain in His victOry,
Who lived, who died, who lives again
To Him all power is given;
No place too high for Him is found,
No place too high in heaven.
He fills the throne, the throne above,
The object of His Father's love,
Though high yet He presents the praise
The faintest, feeblest lay they raise
This song be ours, and this alone
Of Him who sits upon the throne, And that exalts His name.
To Him whom men despise and slight,
The crown is His, and His by right
head that once was crowned with
Delight of all who dwell above,
To us He manifests His love
That we its depths may know.
To us His cross with all its shame,
With all its grace is given;
Though earth disowns the lowly name,
To us His cross is life and health,
Though shame and death to Him; Our present glory, joy, and wealth,
Son of God, who dwelt in light
Came forth as man the foe to fight,
In perfect light was sin made bare,
While perfect love in triumph there
Who but the sinless One could be
And who in heaven or earth save He
Could cleanse us with His blood?
Exalted now at God's right hand
Eternal proof that God is just,
And proof that God is love.
For Jesus is the bright reward,
Beneath the earth awhile He lies,
A Victor soon the Lord will rise,
He saw the cross, despised its shame,
For this He bears the greatest name,
To Him shall every knee be bowed,
And bear Him to the throne.
We think we see the glorious King
Let saints on earth their tribute bring,
For He who saves them is the King
"Lamb of God," with one accord! Thousand, thousand saints replying
Wake at once the echoing chord.
Praise the Lamb! the chorus waking,
Loud and far, each tongue partaking,
All the mind of heaven is one.
All the Son's effulgence beaming Makes the Father's glory known.
Crowd with light and joy unfading, Hail Him as the great I AM.
Hark! the heavenly notes of praises.—
of kings and Lord of lords—
Let His people raise their song.
He is on the throne above,
Jesus, who told out God's love.
Heaven and earth His name record.
Power and praise to Him belong,
Rich in glory, Christ did stoop, Thence is all His people's hope.
He was poor that we might be
The strife is o'er, the battle done,
Oh, let the song of praise be sung,
The powers of death have done their
Christ Jesus hath His foes dispersed;
Let shouts of praise and joy outburst,
On that third day He rose again
Oh, let us swell the joyful strain,
When we think of love like this,
Joy and shame our hearts possess;
Joy that He could pity thus,
Shame for such return from us.
Yet we soon the day shall see
When we shall from sin be free,
There to praise God as we ought.
He overcame the power of hell,
The bars from heaven's high portals fell;
Let songs of joy His triumph tell, Hallelujah!
From death's dread sting to set us free,
That we, 0 God, may sing to
Comes to claim His great reward;
Friends and foes shall hear His voice;
Tremble, tremble, ye that hate Him.
Ye who love His name rejoice.
Lo, the Man on earth rejected,
Day and night they cry before Him,
All the powers of heaven adore Him, All obey His sovereign word.
Then haste, ye saints, your tribute bring
Loox, ye saints, the sight is glorious,
See the Man of Sorrows now!
Every knee to Him shall bow.
See the Saviour God has crowned!
Rich the trophies that He brings; In the seat of power enthroned,
While the vault of heaven rings.
Crowned the Saviour King of kings.
Mocking thus the Saviour's claim; Saints and angels crowd around Him,
Own His title, praise His name.
Oh, what joy the sight affords!
King of kings and Lord of lords.
Christ the Lord, the Living One;
All His toil on earth completed,
All His work for sinners done.
Every knee shall bow before Him,
Who endured the cross and shame.
God doth now His worth proclaim.
Man to Him the cross awarded,
Christ was claimed on earth who died.
Opened first the tale of grace.
Son of Man, in new creation
Own Him in the highest place.
Crowns of glory are His right, His who liveth and was dead.
Jesus fought and won the day,
Such a day was never fought! Well His people now may say,
See what God, our God, has wrought.
He subdued the powers of hell;
In the fight He stood alone;
All His foes before Him fell,
They have fallen to rise no more,
His the fight, the arduous toil,
His the honours of the day,
His the glory and the spoil,
Lord of glory! Who is He?
Who is the King of glory?
Only the Son of God can be
The Christ, the King of glory.
Consider all His wounds, and see
How Jesus' death upon the tree
Above all heavens at God's right hand
Now sits the King of glory.
The angels by His favour stand
Swiftly they fly at His command
To guard His own of every land,
To keep the heirs of glory.
Death and the grave confess the Lamb
To be the King of glory;
The powers of darkness dread His name,
Thrice happy who in Him believe,
They soon shall share His glory;
Born of His Spirit, they receive
Taught by His cross. for sin they grieve;
He calls them brethren, and they cleave
To Him, their hope of glory.
THE mighty work is done; He who the victory won
No more will die; He lives on high,
Our praise to God we bring—
God has raised Him from the dead;
Now He lives our glorious Head.
He sitteth now: to Him all bow;
Our praise to God we bring—
God has seated Him on high,
And by Him we are brought nigh.
He comes soon to the air,
And we shall meet Him there,
Oh glorious hour of heavenly power!
And heaven's high vault shall ring.
We shall know His love and grace
When we look upon His face.
He comes to earth to reign,
The Lamb that once was slain.
His bounteous hand in every land Proclaims Him heaven's King.
Soon He comes to earth again
As the King of kings to reign.
veil is rent! Lo, Jesus sits
The incense which His name emits
His precious blood is sprinkled there
And His own wounds in heaven declare
His work on earth is done.
" 'Tis finished," on the cross He said In agonies and blood;
" 'Tis finished," now He lives to plead
" 'Tis finished," here our souls can rest,
By Him, our sacrifice and Priest,
Before Thy throne Thy people fall
Boldly our heart and voice we raise,
His name, His blood, our plea,
'Tis past, the dark and dreary night;
Our morning Star, without a cloud Of sadness on His brow.
His path on earth, the cross, the grave,
And oh, sweet thought ! His eye shall weep,
His heart shall break no more.
Deep were those sorrows, deeper still
The love that brought Him low,
That bade the streams of life from Him
The soldier, as he pierced Him, proved
Man's hate to Him and Thee,
Whilst in the blood that stained the spear
His love and Thine we see.
It is not that we know the joy
But happier far, the saints are called
So closely are we linked in love
That all His bliss and glory soon
By faith we see the glory
Of which Thou dost assure us, The world despise
Which Thou hast set before us.
And swell the praise of heaven.
The love that blesses us below
Is flowing freely to us now.
The veil is rent in twain,
Why stand we, then, without in fear?
The blood of Christ invites us near.
Is clear and free and bright
With love and peace and day.
Into the Holies now we come—
Has made and keeps us clean.
With boldness let us now draw near,
That blood has banished every fear.
To Him who has been slain
He loves us, cleansed us by His blood,
Made us a kingdom, priests to God.
far we see the glorious day When He who bore our sins away
A Man of Sorrows once He was;
No friend was found to plead His cause,
For all preferred the world's applause.
He groaned beneath sin's awful load,
For in the sinner's place He stood,
And died to bring us nigh to God.
But now He reigns with glory crowned,
While angel hosts the throne surround, And still His lofty praises sound.
And there is yet a day to come
When He who suffered in our room
Will take His waiting people home.
He lives in heaven, their great High Priest,
And bears their names upon His breast.
But Justice now withstands no more
And Mercy yields her boundless store.
In Him the shadows of the law
Are all fulfilled, and now withdraw.
Hid from the eyes of men, His people look to see
In brightest glory He will come
And take His waiting people home.
Sits with God upon the throne,
Now no more to be forsaken,
Never more shall God the Father
Smite the Shepherd with the sword;
Set at nought the glorious Lord.
Jesus fills all heaven with incense
On His heart our names are graven,
On His shoulders we are borne.
For His sake the Father loves us;
See Him now in glory seated
Where our sins no more can rise.
Lo, He doth in heaven appear!
Shows the blood of His atonement
As our title to be there.
our sins were laid upon Him,
Jesus bore them on the tree;
God, who knew them, laid them on Him,
God now brings us to His dwelling,
Spreads for us a feast of love,
In that circle of God's favour,
All is rest, and rest for ever,
Yes, " for ever " is the word;
Nought divide them from the Lord.
Section 3. The Excellencies of the Lord Jesus Christ
When, like a tent to dwell in,
He wrought by weight and measure;
And His the sons of men.
Ere stars were seen above; In wisdom He has made us,
To have us for His own,
Which He to us has shown; In spite of all our badness,
He brings us in with gladness
laud the everlasting Word, The Father's only Son,
Worthy the name of Jesus now
That every knee therein should bow.
Worthy the name of Jesus now
That every knee therein should bow.
Worthy the name of Jesus now
That every knee therein should bow.
But the high mysteries of His name
Worthy the name of Jesus now
That every knee therein should bow.
Yet loving Him, on whom God's love
As one with Him are blest.
Worthy the name of Jesus now
That every knee therein should bow.
Of the vast universe of bliss
Th' eternal theme of praise is this—
Worthy the name of Jesus now
That every knee therein should bow.
let us sing this song of love,
Of Him who came from heaven above;
He made the worlds by His great power,
And keeps them till the final hour.
And none can stay His hand or say
"What doest Thou? Thy wonders cease." He is the God of power and peace.
rules through heaven and earth and hell,
His creatures all His wonders tell;
In His own hand He holds the seas,
He guides the tide, controls the breeze;
The frost, the snow, the ice, the cold,
All are by His great power controlled;
And yet an infant Babe He lay
In Bethlehem's manger on that day.
The One who dwells in heaven so high
We see within the manger lie;
Th' eternal God, a little Child,
So gentle, quiet, meek and mild.
He came His Father to obey,
Our sins by death to put away; Came to redeem us and to save
From sin, from death and from the grave.
To God our joyful praise we bring;
His love, His power to save we sing.
Our hearts adore Thee now, 0 God;
We trace with joy the path He trod.
With heart and voice we sing this day,
And humbly we our homage pay;
We wait to see His glorious face,
And evermore to sing Thy grace.
Be to Him who bare the cross,
Who redeemed our souls by tasting Death, the death deserved by us!
His is love, 'tis love unbounded, Without measure, without end;
Of the Saviour's cross and shame,
Be to God and to the Lamb." Hallelujah!
Give ye glory to His name.
Than the rich gems and polished gold
They first their own sin-offering brought
His life was pure, without a spot,
Fresh blood as constant as the day
But His one offering takes away For ever all our guilt.
Their range was earth, nor higher soared,
The heaven of heavens is His;
And sing the great Redeemer's praise.
He saw us ruined in the Fall,
He saved us from our lost estate;
Soon shall we mount and soar away
To those bright realms of endless day,
And sing with rapture and surprise,
let us raise a joyful song
And join with heaven's angelic throng
That was slain on Mount Calvary.
"Worthy the One who died," they cry,
And blessings, more than we can give,
Let all that dwell above the sky,
And air, and earth, and seas,
Conspire to raise His glories high,
Creation soon shall join in one
Of Him who sits upon the throne,
Now in a song of grateful praise
To God we will our voices raise;
With gladsome hearts we'll join to tell—
Christ Jesus hath done all things well.
All worlds His glorious power confess, His wisdom all His works express,
But, oh, His love what tongue can tell?
Christ Jesus hath done all things well.
He plucked us from the jaws of hell;
Christ Jesus hath done all things well.
We spurned His grace, we broke His
And yet He undertook our cause, [laws,
To save us though we did rebel;
Christ Jesus hath done all things well.
And when to that bright world we rise
And sing our anthem in the skies,
Above the rest this note shall swell—
Christ Jesus hath done all things well.
Chorus at the end of the hymn
Christ Jesus hath done all things well.
JESUS! that name all names above,
The wealth of God's infinite grace.
What mind can grasp, what tongue proclaim
The value of that peerless name?
Jesus! a note of sweeter sound
Not e'en in heaven itself is found;
It thrills with joy the heart of God,
This name of the incarnate Word.
What mind can grasp, what tongue proclaim
The sweetness of that peerless name?
Jesus! the name that ne'er can fail
To make the powers of darkness quail;
To fear-wrung hearts gives lasting peace,
What mind can grasp, what tongue proclaim
The prowess of that peerless name?
Jesus! the name which can impart
True solace to each sorrowing heart;
Of death subdue the sting and gloom,
With heavenly glory gild the tomb.
What mind can grasp, what tongue proclaim
The comfort of that peerless name?
Jesus! the name through which alone
To God their hearts' desires outpour
And draw from heaven's exhaustless store.
What mind can grasp, what tongue proclaim
The riches of that peerless name?
Jesus! the name in which shall bow
Each knee in heaven, on earth, below;
May we each day by day proclaim The glory of that peerless name.
And when we pass to realms above,
See Him who taught us heavenly love,
The virtues of that peerless name!
Thy rest is in Thy Son;
Thy rest and ours are one.
Inside the circle of Thy love
Joined to His life are we above;
How sweet with Thee, 0 God, to share
The joy which is Thy portion there!
Thou findest in that spotless One,
All that Thy heart could wish for us,
All that Thou e'er couldst tell;
Where all Thy joys transcendent are,
In Him a people for Thy praise,
We stand accepted in the place
That none but Christ could claim.
Our willing hearts have heard Thy voice,
And in Thy mercy we rejoice.
That Thou shouldst place us in Thy
Thy perfect love hath cast out fear,
Thy favour shines upon us here.
Now of His peace, His joy, possessed, We wait His face to see.
Now to Thy heart, 0 God, received,
We know Thee whom we have believed.
COME, let us sing the matchless worth,
And sweetly sound the praises forth,
To God our praise of Christ we'll bring,
The song with which the heavens ring
How rich that precious blood once spilt, Our rescue from the dreadful guilt
Great are the offices He bears,
In songs of sweet, untiring praise
We would to everlasting days Make all His glories known.
And soon the happy day shall come
When we shall reach our destined home,
And see Him face to face;
Then with our Saviour, Master, Friend,
Who all Thy will hath done;
And by the one chief treasure
Thine own pure love we measure,
From Christ's most precious name. What always sounds so sweetly
When nought beside could ease us
Or set our souls at large, The precious blood of Jesus
More marred than men to be,
Who pierced Him on the tree.
we adore Him who came from Thy side
Leaving the glory that heaven could provide,
Wonderful gift of the Father of love.
We will remember Him, keeping His word
Sacrificed, bearing our sins on the tree.
We will remember His coming to earth,
There as a Babe we behold Him at birth,
God in this world here to dwell.
Laid in a manger, eternally God!
We will remember His wonderful life,
Perfect obedience midst sorrow and strife
Loving and giving each step of the way.
We will remember His death on the tree,
Suffering the just for the unjust was He;
Giving Himself, our Redeemer to be.
We will remember He rose from the dead,
Living for ever, our glorious Head
Conquered the power of the grave.
Praises for Him we present unto Thee.
As we now thank offerings bring;
Best of gifts, His Son from heaven.
Who tune their songs to Jesus' name,
All merit of their own deny,
Firm on the ground of sovereign grace
The only song in that blest place
Death's dark flood has entered in,
Suffered all the judgment throes, Saved us from eternal woes.
Sits He at His Father's side.
Giving us in Christ a place,
Songs resounding with His praise; Hallelujah! strike the chord,
To Him who sits upon the throne;
And to the Lamb, whose blood was shed
" Thou, Thou art worthy, Thou alone;
For Thou wast slain, and in Thy blood
These robes were washed so spotless pure;
Thou mad'st us kings and priests to God,
For ever let Thy praise endure."
Let us with joy adopt the strain
We hope to sing for ever there
" Worthy the Lamb for sinners slain,
Worthy alone the crown to wear!"
Without one thought that's good to plead,
Oh, what could shield us from despair,
But this—though we are vile indeed,
The Lord our righteousness is there?
THOUGH all the beasts that live and feed,
Upon a thousand hills should bleed,
Though all their blood should flow,
The sacrifice would be in vain;
The stain of sin would still remain;
It needs, the conscience to appease,
No blood hath virtue to atone
For man's offence, but His alone
Jesus the Christ, on earth His name, He came, in love to sinners came,
And bowed His head and died.
A full atonement now is made,
The ransom by His death is paid,
That sinners might draw near to Him, God planned this great, this wondrous
Let all the saints their voices raise,
And sing the great Redeemer's praise,
Section 4. The Fruits of the Accomplished Work
Jesus, the Sun, our night broke through
The Son came from His throne above His wandering sheep to save.
No more the heirs of wrath, The smile of peace we see,
And triumphing o'er sin and death
The love which Thou hast made to beam
From Christ the Heir of heaven.
We soon shall see Him there,
With Him and them before Thee stand,
And we have peace with God: 'Tis everlasting peace.
The clouds may come and go,
And storms may sweep our sky;
Our love is of ttimes low,
Our joy still ebbs and flows,
But peiice with Him remains the same,
His love, not ours, the resting-place,
His truth, not ours, the tie.
Though heaven is now His home;
The mighty stone is rolled away,
The grave of all our woes;
We know the Son of God has come,
We know He died and rose.
We know the throne on which He sits,
We know His truth and love.
No flame, no smoke ascends on high,
The lamb is slain no more;
But richer blood has flowed from nobler veins,
To purge the soul from guilt, and cleanse the
We thank Thee for the blood—
The blood of Christ, Thy Son;
The blood by which our peace was made,
Great victOry o'er hell, and sin, and woe,
That needs no second fight, and leaves no second foe.
We thank Thee for the grace
Love of the Father's co-eternal Son,
Th' eternal Spirit's love—Jehovah, Three in One!
We thank Thee for the hope,
So glad, and sure, and clear;
It holds the drooping spirit up
Fair hope, with what a sunshine does it cheer
Our roughest path on earth, our dreariest desert here!
'TB we, 0 God, whom Thou hast shown
We, who forgiving love have known, May fitly bring thank-offerings in.
Thy presence called for Israel's praise,
And when in death they met their gaze
What songs of glorious triumph rose!
And we have known redemption, Lord,
From bondage worse than theirs by far; Sin held us by a stronger cord,
Yet by Thy mercy free we are.
The blest Redeemer's groans and tears,
His death the power of darkness broke;
Bursting the chains we wore for years
He freed us from the iron yoke.
Thy people from the deep could bring;
The glorious triumph all His own—
His name, His might, His grace we sing.
Section 5. Our Access into the Holies
the bread and for the wine,
For the pledge that seals Him mine,
For the words of love divine,
Yet to faith the solemn sign
For the words that turn the eye
Bidding us in faith draw nigh,
For the words that fragrance breathe,
Words that His own peace bequeath,
For the words that tell of home,
Till He come we take the bread,
Type of Him on whom we feed,
Him who liveth and was dead;
He come we drink the wine,
Of His blood the solemn sign,
For that day to man unknown,
For the glory and the throne,
THIS broken bread and poured-out wine
Though loomed Golgotha in His view,
His forethought made this statute new
" This in remembrance of Me do;"
The loaf He took spake of that frame,
Prepared by God for Him who came
He gave God thanks, the loaf He brake;
"My body this, given for your sake,"
Words such as these in love He spake,
How solemn is the broken bread!
Sign of His holy body, dead,
Who suffered in our room and stead;
For He of blood and flesh took part;
The cup of wine poured out we see;
This speaks of pardon full and free,
But tells of His deep agony—
His woe and travail now are o'er;
He who sin's dreadful burden bore
A few times more, if so it be,
And then with joy Himself we see—
To suffer once to earth Christ came,
And now He's crowned in heaven.
His blood shed once for all,
This broken loaf and poured-out cup
Our theme of joy and wonder here,
Who has redeemed us by His blood,
And now as our High Priest above Lives as our Advocate with God.
We never would forget the pain,
The blood-like sweat, the shameful tree,
The wrath His soul did once sustain,
From sin and death to set us free.
In broken bread and out-poured wine
We hear Him say, " Remember Me;
I gave My life, a price divine,
I bore the wrath to set you free."
0 God, we gladly praise His love,
Who suffered for us on the tree;
And till He come from heaven above
We keep His word—" Remember Me."
To Thee, 0 God, our voice we raise
How great Thou art in holiness!
Didst sanctify us by the blood
Raised from the dust of earth are we
To be a priesthood unto Thee,
We stand before Thee in His name;
0 God, we have no other claim
But here in Him, our holy Lord,
We praise Thy name with one accord;
Our praise ascends through Christ the
The great High Priest is He.
The Spirit gives us power to raise
Our heart and voice in holy praise, In holy praise to Thee.
We praise Thee for the matchless grace
Which gives us in Thy love a place
Unto Thy name for ever be
For love so freely given. Amen.
Though great may be our dulness
In thought and word and deed,
Of Him who meets our need.
Before th' eternal throne; God graciously is bending
Our names to Thee is bringing,
For us He wears the mitre
For us His robes are whiter
Of Jesus Christ our Lord, In Him we are before Thee,
A kingdom He has made us,
And we (as Thou hast bade us)
We think with joy, yet sadness,
Of how He stooped to die,
And praise Thy name with gladness
We praise Thee for the savour
Who brought such glory to Thee,
He was for Thee an offering
He gave Thee boundless pleasure, He Thee delighteth still.
With reverent hearts and holy awe
We plead not our own virtues,
But by the blood of Jesus
But as a holy priesthood now
Our great High Priest before us
Though not of earthly gifts received
We praise Thee and we worship,
For giving up Thy Son to death
For sins which we had done.
Have brought us nigh to Thee,
To Thee we bow the knee.
How for us He left the glory
As a Man 'mongst men to dwell,
Thus to rescue us from hell.
Firstfruits of our lies to God,
Fruit of lips we join in singing
As we raise our loud hosannas,
Is the theme that fills our heart;
On the cross for our redemption
He was pierced with judgment's dart.
For us bearing sin's vast load;
All the wrath of God endured,
Paid our debt with His life's blood.
In the silent grave they lay Him,
Seal the stone and guard it well.
Powerless all the hosts of hell.
He comes forth o'er death victorious,
See Him now the risen One,
Prince of life and King of glory,
Prophet, Priest and King, behold Him,
Praise His name with one accord.
Saints on earth their voices raising
Shout the praises, bless the name
Of the One who died to save us,
holy, holy, we now come before Thee,
Gathered in that holy name so very dear to Thee.
0 Lord God, we own Thee, humbly we adore Thee,
For Thy grace and power and truth and love we see.
Thou Thy Son hast given, see His body riven,
Pierced with cruel thorn and spear upon Golgotha's tree. For our sins He suffered, and His body offered,
And His blood outpoured a sacrifice to Thee.
Now through Jesus' merit, gathered by the Spirit,
Here within the holy place, through Him we boldly c
Hearts and voices blending, praise to Thee ascending,
Through our great High Priest we worship Thee alone.
Holy, holy, holy, humbly we adore Thee,
Honour, blessing, power and might we would ascribe to
Courts of heaven ringing with the praise were bringing,
For the One who lives our living Lord to be.
By Thy blest Spirit hither led;
We bring our sacrifice of praise,
Assured by Him a heavenly place!
Ere worlds at Thy command were made,
How could Thy heart such love conceive—
To slay Thy Son and us receive?
To charge with guilt the Holy One,
The stream of love divine alone
Through Christ could pardon and atone;
And at the cross its fulness showed.
Accepted through His death are we
To be a priesthood, serving Thee.
What joy is ours, through saving grace,
To worship in the holy place!
Thus boldly we now enter in,
Cleansed by Christ's blood from every sin;
It speaks for us before Thy throne,
Great God, Thy love all love excels; It humbles us, yet praise compels! Eternally our song shall be
Of Him who said, " Remember Me."
And the outside place. There we see Him dying,
Of the love that's owed Thee
We hear His cry of sorrow
0 God, what grace and kindness In all His actions shine!
Our sins were laid upon Him,
And thus our debt was paid.
Freed by such love, we ponder
That brings us in with gladness
Would praise Thee for Thy Son,
That Thou, through Him, hast done.
THOU wondrous God, we love to trace The riches of Thy matchless grace;
Thou, ere the worlds were made, didst plan
To seek and save poor ruined man.
We cannot praise Thee as we ought. Thy love excels our highest thought!
Thou didst Thy Son in pity give,
That sinners through His death might live;
He suffered on the shameful tree
We cannot praise Him as we ought,
His love excels our highest thought!
Who giiides us to our heavenly rest,
Makes these poor hearts His dwelling place,
To whisper there the tale of grace.
We cannot praise Him as we ought,
His love excels our highest thought!
Christ shall bring us in to Thee,
We'll praise Thy grace more worthily;
With all the blood-bought hosts above
We fain would praise Thee as we ought,
Thy love excels our highest thought!
Stand up and bless the Lord your God
With heart and soul and voice.
Who would not fear His holy name,
To touch our lips, our mind inspire,
And wing to heaven our thought!
God is our strength and song,
Then be His love in Christ proclaimed,
Stand up and bless the Lord,
Stand up and bless His glorious name
Known through the earth by thousand
Those mighty orbs proclaim Thy power,
And on the wings of every hour
But when we view Thy great design
Our souls are filled with awe divine
For the bright glories of Christ's name
Fill heaven and earth with praise;
Let joy and wonder tune each heart
In light inaccessible hid from our eyes,
Most blessed, most glorious, the Ancient of days,
Almighty, victorious, Thy great name we praise.
Unresting, unhasting, and silent as light,
Nor wanting, nor wasting, Thou rulest in might;
Thy justice like mountains high soaring above,
clouds are as fountains of goodness and love.
To all life Thou givest, to great and to small;
In all life Thou livest, the true life of all.
We blossom and flourish as leaves on the tree,
And wither and perish, but nought changeth Thee.
Great Father of glory, pure Father of light,
Thine angels adore Thee, all veiling their sight;
All praise we would render, Oh help us to see
'Tis only the splendour of light hideth Thee.
light inaccessible hid from our eyes,
Most blessed, most glorious, the Ancient of days,
Almighty, victorious, Thy great name we praise.
The world, created by His hands,
Firm on its first foundation stands.
But ere this spacious world was made Or had its first foundation laid,
For ever shall Thy throne endure, Thy promise stands for ever sure;
Becomes the dwelling of Thy grace.
and adore! how glorious He That dwells in bright eternity;
We gaze and we confound our sight,
Plunged in th' abyss of dazzling light.
What lofty numbers shall we frame,
Seraphs that stand around the throne Begin and speak the great Unknown;
Attempt the song, wind up your strings To notes untried and boundless things.
Largely beyond our eyes of clay,
Yet what a narrow portion too
Is seen, or known, or thought by you!
How flat your highest praises fall
Weak creatures we that strive in vain
Great God, forgive our feeble lays,
Sound out Thine own eternal praise;
A song so vast, a theme so high,
Calls for the voice that tuned the sky.
Before Thy holy throne we bow;
We worship Thee, Thou God of love,
Past, present, future, still the same.
Displays the wonders of Thy name.
Thou triune God, there's none beside; With Thee the honour none can share.
Far, far above earth's pomp and pride,
With Thee none ever can compare.
Yet One from Thee, oh, matchless grace, Oh, wondrous mystery divine,
In human form did take man's place,
And God and man in one combine!
The Christ of God, in Him we see
And now He lives on high enthroned,
Yes, now He lives no more to die.
He who by death for sin atoned
Now lives to bring His people nigh.
Through Him to God we now draw near,
Of Him to God our praises bring.
God for His sake will deign to hear,
And to accept the songs we sing.
is the work, our God and King,
To praise Thy name, give thanks and sing,
To show Thy love by morning light,
And tell of all Thy truth by night.
Our hearts shall triumph in Thee, Lord,
And bless Thy works and bless Thy word;
Thy works of grace, how bright they shine,
How deep Thy counsels, how divine!
But if the little that we know
Of Thee and Thine while here below
Such triumph gives, what will it be
When face to face Thyself we see?
What can we render unto Thee
For all that Thou for us bast done
When Israel's sons Thy presence sought,
The best of that received from Thee.
As reverently Thy courts they trod
They praised and worshipped Thee, their
For victeries Thine arm achieved, [God, For earthly benefits received.
Then what more fitting now can we
Give, 0 Thou blessed God, to Thee
Than of the best that Thou hast given,
Thy gift of gifts sent down from heaven?
We make confession to His name,
To do Thy will, to meet our need,
For Thee to live, for us to bleed.
His worth to compass to the full,
We yet would speak of Him to Thee;
Dear to Thyself and us is He.
We would adore Thee, God of love,
Through whom Thou hast Thyself made
In His blest name our voice we raise In songs of gratitude and praise;
SEE mercy, mercy from on high
Descend to rebels doomed to die.
'Tis mercy free which knows no bound,
How grand, how gladsome is the sound!
Soon as the reign of sin began
The light of mercy dawned on man, When God announced the early news,
" The woman's Seed thy head shall
Brightly it beamed on man forlorn,
When Christ, the holy Child, was born.
And in its fullest splendour shone
It triumphed when from death He rose
And brake the power of all His foes;
And since He took His seat on high
God of wonders, all Thy ways
But the bright glories of Thy grace
Who is a pardoning God like Thee,
Or who hath grace so rich and free?
Such guilty daring worms to spare—
And in this honour none shall share.
Who is a pardoning God like Thee,
Or who hath grace so rich and free?
Pardon for sins of deepest dye,
Pardon that brings the rebel nigh;
Who is a pardoning God like Thee,
Or who hath grace so rich and free?
Thy mercy, Lord, shall aye endure;
Thy word abides for ever sure.
He formed the earth and seas
Thy power and grace are still the same;
To crown the day with light,
Thy mercy, Lord, shall aye endure;
Thy word abides for ever sure.
Thy power and grace are still the same;
Let endless praise exalt Thy name.
To save us from our woe,
Thy mercy, Lord, shall aye endure;
Thy word abides for ever sure.
Thy power and grace are still the same;
Who did provide the Lamb—The merit of His precious blood
And through His Son it flows;
Once slain for us, for us He lives,
He who was slain is seen
And His redeemed are white and clean
Our hearts are tuned for this,
Christ is the spring of all our bliss,
For Him who cleansed us by His blood,
Thou God of power and God of love,
The seraphs in the realms above
And veil their faces while they cry,
"Thrice holy" to their God Most High,
Thee as our God we too would claim,
And bless the precious Saviour's name
Through whom this grace is given;
Who bore the wrath to sinners due,
Who formed our ruined souls anew,
And made us heirs of heaven.
Give us to know the joy and love
With which all worship Thee above
Here to our hearts Thyself reveal,
And all assembled cause to feel The presence of our God.
Calls for homage due to Thee.
By Thy blessed Son brought nigh,
Cleansed and clothed as priests we bring
All things working to fulfil Counsels of Thy sovereign will.
Shown by gifts Thy creatures share,
For that One of matchless worth,
Who so fully told Thee forth.
In the work He wrought we see
For the life He lived below,
For the cross with all its woe,
We would praise and worship Thee.
Ransomed souls the tidings swell; 'Tis a deep that knows no sounding,
Who its breadth or length can tell?
Let our souls for ever dwell.
What from Christ the soul can sever,
Once in Him, in Him for ever—
From the Strength of Israel's hands.
Love eternal in Christ chose us,
Long ere time its race began.
What the love of God has done;
On such love let us still ponder,
Say, while lost in holy wonder,
"Why are we, Lord, loved by Thee?"
PRAISE we now the Father's love—
He has sent the heavenly Dove,
Christ has sent Him to abide,
Sent by God in Jesus' name,
Three in One and One in Three,
'TWAS Thy love, 0 God, that knew us
That same love to Jesus drew us
God of love, our souls adore Thee,
We would still Thy grace proclaim,
Till we cast our crowns before Thee
And in glory praise Thy name.
Be to God and to the Lamb.
SOFT the voice of mercy sounded
Sweet as music to the ear;
" Grace abounds where sin abounded," This the word that soothed our fear. Grace, the sweetest sound we know,
Grace we sing, God's grace through Jesus,
Grace, the spring of peace to man;
Grace that from each sorrow frees us,
Grace too high for thought to scan;
Grace, the theme of God's own love,
Grace, the theme all themes above.
Trinity, from mortal sight Veiled in Thine own eternal light,
We Thee confess, in Thee believe,
To Thee with loving hearts we cleave.
With Thee is Thine eternal Son,
The Three in One whom we adore.
The Father is in God the Son,
And with the Father He is one;
In Both the Spirit doth abide,
And with Them Both is glorified.
Such as the Father, such the Son,
And such the Spirit, Three in One. The Three one perfect Verity,
One only God our hearts adore.
Now let our praise accepted be. Amen.
Holy, holy, holy, merciful and mighty,
God in three Persons, blessed Trinity.
Holy, holy, holy, all the saints adore Thee,
Worshipping with gladness we now make melody; Cherubim and seraphim falling down before Thee,
Who wert, and art, and evermore
the eye of mortal man Thy glory cannot see,
Only Thou art holy, there is none
Holy, holy, holy, Lord God Almighty,
All Thy works shall praise Thy name, in earth and sky and sea:
Holy, holy, holy, merciful and mighty,
God in three Persons, blessed Trinity. Amen.
ye Jehovah, praise the Lord most holy,
Who cheers the contrite, girds with strength the weak;
Praise Him who will with glory crown the lowly,
And with salvation beautify the meek.
Praise ye the Lord for all His loving-kindness,
And all the tender mercies He has shown;
Praise Him who pardons all our sins and blindness,
And calls us sons and takes us for His own.
Holy, holy, holy, Lord God Almighty,
On this Lordly morn our song we raise to Thee;
Holy, holy, holy, merciful and mighty,
God in three Persons, blessed Trinity.
Praise ye Jehovah, source of every blessing,
Viewed with His gifts, earth's brightest boons are dim;
Resting on Him, His peace and joy possessing,
All things are ours, for we have all in Him.
Praise ye the Father, God the Lord, who gave us
With full and perfect love His only Son;
Praise ye the Son, who died Himself to save us;
Praise ye the Spirit; praise the Three in One.
Holy, holy, holy, Lord God Almighty,
On this Lordly morn our song we raise to Thee;
Holy, holy, holy, merciful and mighty,
God in three Persons, blessed Trinity. Amen.
the One who hath been slain
He hath redeemed us with His blood,
And we will praise His name, 0 God,
In heaven more sweet and loud;
To Him who cleansed our sins
To Him (we sing in joyful strain)
Be honour, power and praise; Amen.
His was the shame and loss,
The mighty work was all His own,
Though we shall share His glorious throne.
To Him who bare the cross, Its awful load sustained,
And the great victory gained, To Him (we sing in joyful strain)
Be honour, power and praise; Amen.
Him who loved us, gave us
Every pledge that love could give,
Freely shed His blood to save us,
Gave His life that we might live,
For of Thee and through Thee
And to Thee are all things.
We bless Thee, we praise Thee;
To keep us from falling, And faultless to set us
Be unto the Lamb for ever.
To the Lord God, who keepeth
servants of Jah Jehovah, Bless ye, bless ye Jehovah.
Praise Him and magnify Him for ever.
God of love, to all eternity;
God of truth, to all eternity;
Let us praise His holy name.
to the Holiest in the height,
And in the depth be praise;
In all His words most wonderful,
Most sure in all His ways. Amen.
to the Father praise, Give glory to the Son,
And to the Spirit of His grace
God, from whom all blessings flow,
Praise Him, His people here below;
Praise Him above, ye heavenly host,
Praise Father, Son and Holy Ghost.
To the Father, to the Son,
To the Spirit, praise be given;
One in Three and Three in One,
Lord of earth and Lord of heaven.

HERE, blessed God, we see Him face to face; Here faith can touch and handle things unseen;
Here would we grasp with firmer hands His grace,
And all our weariness upon Him lean.
Here would we feed upon the bread of God,
Here drink with Him the royal wine of heaven;
Here would we lay aside each earthly load,
Here taste afresh the calm of sin forgiven.
We have no help but His, nor do we need
Another arm save His to lean upon.
It is enough, 0 God, enough indeed,
Our strength is in His might, His might alone.
Ours is the sin, but His the righteousness,
Ours is the guilt, but His the cleansing blood.
Here is our robe, our refuge, and our peace,
The righteousness He wrought, 0 Lord our God.
Too soon we rise, the symbols disappear,
the love, is past and gone;
The bread and wine remove, but He is here,
Nearer than ever, still our Shield and Sun.
Feast after feast thus comes and passes by,
Yet passing points to the glad feast above,
Giving sweet foretastes of the festal joy,
The Lamb's great bridal feast of bliss and love.
We go from strength to strength
Through this dark vale of tears,
The fulness of the rapturous song
To Christ the Saviour's endless praise.
Heaven's blissful cadence, deep and loud,
While every heart before the throne
In holy, solemn awe is bowed.
Be ours to mingle with the throng
of the worlds above, How pleasant and how fair
With warm desire To see our God.
There is Thy throne of grace,
Nothing left for us to do
But to enter on His toil,
His the pardon, ours the sin—
Great the sin, the pardon great;
His the good, and ours the ill;
His the love, and ours the hate.
His the labour, ours the rest;
His the death, and ours the life;
He has sown the precious seed,
Ours it is to reap the field,
Make the harvest joy our own.
JEHOVAH God the Father, bless and keep
His little flock of feeble lambs and sheep;
Jehovah God the Son, His glorious face
Make shine on us, so full of kindly grace;
His countenance, and grant us peace, His gift.
Eternal triune God, with love inflame
Our souls, to praise Thy great Jehovah name. Amen, amen.
Would feed, and live, and grow;
Go on to know Thee, Lord,
THIS is the day the Lord hath made,
He calls the hours His own.
Let heaven rejoice, let earth be glad,
Today He rose and left the dead,
Today the saints His triumph spread,
Help us, 0 Lord, on this blest day,
To spread the glad, good news,
And may Thy gospel's healing ray
Lord, in Thy grace we came;
We met in Thine own name
And in Thy name we part.
With gladsome hearts we now would bring
Blessed are they that dwell in Thy house,
They will be still praising Thee.
